This particular build is a tool of war, plain and simple he is a devastating spell-sword that has no weaknesses. Count the tools at his disposal, fully undispellable arcane caster that has access to both - best epic spells in the game, and then can penetrate SR 32 in a roll of just "2", but also he is epic focussed in the school of his choice! And as if those were not enough, he is claded in plate mail and shield, fully capable of unleashing his destractive spells while wearing the heviest of the armours, and he is a master of swords too, with epic specialization and improved knockdown to name a few of his skills. Amongst the spell-swords he is the only one undispellable caster that can look straight in the eyes - and not falter, the dragonic champions of both spell and blade with a natural AB of 39 and 4 attacks/ round. Good saves that become great against magical spells hurled from his enemies, and more skill points than you might know what to do with them, the "Abjurant Champion" is a cutting-edge weapon ready to be unleashed. Have fun and good hunting!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
A dwarven invoker armed with beard and battleaxe!
I like the build. A good BAB and strength with casting in full armor. You beat standard toolset SR except on a roll of 1. ESF evocation gives a spell DC that can get the job done in most cases, especially if you buff/max intelligence.
A well conceived spell-Axe!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Thanks Mick, the work involved in this case was a lot but i feel it was worth it at the end. After i posted my "eldritch disciple" build, i tinkered again and again with the build's structure, changing the level order, the race and all that is involved till i finally got a fourth attack with the same ab and another epic spell, which i felt it was a big improvement considering how "tight" these (26/xx/yy) builds are. I should do an update to the "eldritch disciple" as well now that i am thinking of it, and i will as soon as i finish my new smiter. Anyway, long story-short i then considered to change the classes from sorcerer to wizard and with that i choose to go with a dwarf as well not that charisma wasn't a factor in the build, and the results amazed me! This build not only achieves a really good unbuffed ab for a spell-blade but it also makes the acquisition of the epic spells and auto-still feats a cake. By the time you hit level 33 you can cast all your spells in full plate and by the 36th level you have both of your epic spells as well. That being said, i would like to say something about the stat arrangement of this build. If someone feels like he wants to play it more safely and he isn't an adept in handling mage-knights then he can start with 16 strength and 18 constitution gaining a total of "80 hp's and 2 fort" and loosing only "1 ab and dmg" from his attacks. It is more than a fair trade i think.

Now, about the evocation focus of this build, the reason was twofold. First it was for the theme of being a war-mage and all and nothing feels more flashy and destructive than multiple fireballs and lightnings strikes coming from your fingertips. The real reason though is that i always go with selected schools based on the maximum dc that i can have with my spells. For example necromancy in NwN1 is always the most powerful school of magic but when you cannot have a close to maximum dc it is often better if you select a magic school that focuses on a weaker save than fortitude. Evocation does exactly that and it even has a couple of tricky spells that can stun-lock enemies forever. Pay careful attention to spells like "thunderclap" that has three simultaneous saves and practically it is guaranteed to have an effect on the battlefield. Another very powerful stun-lock effect is "bigby's clenched fist", normally people don't use that one but it is an evocation spell that has a saving throw for the stun effect of it (not for the dmg part) and when you have to make such a save every round a single failure often means to lose the fight. Sunburst is another very powerful "aoe" spell that has a reflex save and permanently blinds your opponents plus it destroys undead and even "firebrand" is very destructive when you lose your save against it. Last one spell that i wanted to mention is "prismatic sprey" i think this spell needs no explanation but in case you have not used it before, then you should start now if you have an evocation focus. Most often than not when i play in epic levels (this is where the spell dc's matter the most) i meet powerful giants and dragons and undead sorcerers as enemies that have really good fortitude and will saves but really weak reflex ones. Having an evocation focus can have a devastating effect on these foes, yes-you have your no-save spells at all (igms, ice storm, bigby's vi and vii, e.t.c) but you also have use for some others now. Ultimately though it is just a matter of preference, you can choose your spell focus freely of course, i just made an argument for the evocation focus based on my experience. Otherwise, necromancy has and will always be a very strong contender with multiple save-or-suck effects.

If however, you use your spell slots only for no-save spells and buffs, then you can always change the spell-focuses with "maximize spell", "craft wands" and "epic spell penetration", those would be my choices. I hope i did not make you all bored with my long monologues at least ;)

Right Jim, the seperation in the Fighter levels was made for the Discipline dumps. As for the Human vversion you would gain simply a feat more and 43 skill points that you don't really need them in this build. Two more feats would be useful but one more is half-way stuff, i suppose you could use it for "maximize spell" or "craft wands". Skill points you have already more than you need and you don't even need to cc skills for rogue abilities because you have the Pixie who will take care of all your rogue needs. Therefore, it is in my opinion that unless you need to be Human for RP purposes or personal preference, staying as a Dwarf is much better. Sad thing that Dwarfs make better Mages than Elves eh? Or anyone else for that reason, except maybe Gnomes for PvP (they escape evard's).

Power attack and Cleave, i do not think they would do much in this build, remember you have your spells too. I am sure taking them in a Fighter but here if i had two more feats i would consider taking "Gsf" in another spell school or something similar.

Your spell focus will indicate some other spells that you will have a relatively good DC and you should pick them. The rest of your spells should be for self-buffs and back-up good old blasting. Such spells are "True Sight", "Mind Blank", "Shadow Shield", "Protection from Spells", Spell Mantle", "Protection from Elements" and so on.

If however you do like the "I need a spell and i need it now" feauture that Sorceress has then she is better. The Sorceress has less knoown spells but she can cast them without mercy whenever she wants them. It is simply a personal preference, and I for example like to play both styles equally. He is taking everything earlier though and he has more Constant Power so to say. Different builds for different tastes but both equally devastating for their opponents, and that is what makes them fun to play.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
It's good to play a strong spell-sword eh? ;-)

And No, the more attacks you have the better it is, no-matter-what. That's because NWN 1 works in "Timed Attacks" you will know them better as "Flurries". Each Round consists of 3 such flurries and your attacks are always divided by that number with the extra attacks going first. If you have 4 attacks then your character will do a rapid two-attack motion and then continue with the third and finally with your forth attack. Now a character that has 4 normal attacks and can haste himself like this one, will attack like this: 2 - 2 -1. So what you see is a very effective Twin Double-Strike attack attack followed by your last Fifth attack at the end. Your last attack usually won't hit, correct, but it pushes the first four of them into twin-attack sequences and because of your high-ab for a spell-sword, most of them hit their targets making you happy. Or perhaps, i don't know what i am talking about, it's late... :-)
